Here is the corrected text:

THE PAPER CRAFT BOOK

J.
Welcome to THE PAPER CRAFT BOOK

Perhaps one of the most innocuous of materials in a craft lover's arsenal, paper can be used in all types of projects. You can create greetings cards with a personal touch, handmade gifts for someone special, decorations with which to revamp your home or even fun projects that'll keep the kids occupied. Either way, master the art with the help of THE PAPER CRAFT BOOK. Explore your artist's toolbox, get acquainted with the materials at your disposal. Then dive straight in by following our simple step-by-step tutorials.

Cheap, accessible and with plenty of impact, projects made from paper are great for craft newbies or old hands who are simply looking for a new storming ground. So turn the page and take your first step in the papercraft world!

30+ Easy Projects

Create your own personalised:

* Greetings cards
* Gift wrap
* Home decorations
* Kids' crafts

Honeycomb Pom-Pom Craft
Daffodils: Layered Papercut Craft

THE PAPER CRAFT BOOK

- BASIC EQUIPMENT -

Basic equipment
One of the great things about meeting crafts from paper is you don't need lots of expensive equipment. We'll list every thing you'll need for each project individually; but the basics covered on this page are used regularly throughout the book, so they are a good investment.

Types of paper

Here is the corrected text:

---

Flexible and reasonably inexpensive; paper is a fantastic and versatile material for craft projects.

Here's an overview of the different types that you'll need, and some details to keep in mind.


Paper Types                            Weight
Unless otherwise stated, the     The greater the weight, the thicker and stronger it will be. Generally speaking, this will be reflected in the cost.

Style                                 Colour
One of the best features of paper is its variety. The number of different patterns and designs available is always endless.

10

....   Tracing Paper                    Tissue Paper
Transparent paper used for copying images, tracing paper is used to transfer templates onto your desired paper or card.
Tracing paper is used to transfer templares onto your desired paper or card.

Crepe Paper                      Origami Paper
A thin, pliable paper perfect for making flowers. If you want to make it stronger, simply snick two sheets together with spray mount.
Usually only one side of origami paper is colored, but this is always the case. The only rules are that it's square and folds well.

Quilling Paper                  Card
Thin strips of paper that are twisted into different shapes. Card is a heavier weight than standard paper and...

To create a square, follow these steps:

1. Fold the paper in half twice to make a square.
2. Then open back out.
3. Fold diagonally, then open out. Open and fold along the center edges into the centre.
4. Fold two of the edges inward so they meet in the middle. Unfold and repeat with the corner sides.

Note: This solution is suitable for use with gift wrap cards.

MINI GIFT BOX

Use slightly stiff paper for the other half of the box.

Coiling and Gluing

To make a coil, place your paper into the quilling tool so no paper emerges from the other side. Wind the paper around the tool using your finger to ensure the coil is flat. You can make different shapes by adjusting how tight the coil is.

34
Quilled Card @


8 Scroll
Heart V Scroll

Shaping and Experimenting


Most quilled shapes are created by making adjustments to the basic coils. For example, to make a marquise you simply create a loose coil and pinch it on either end. To make a teardrop, you do the same but only pinch one end.

Prepare your template and begin to cut away the inside of one of the four panels. Make sure you keep the template right-side up during the whole cutting process.

Papercut Lantern: A Guide to Making Your Own Papercut Lanterns

To make a papercut lantern, you will need to follow these steps:

Pee back the other half of the tape and carefully stick the tracing paper on top. Repeat this process until the tracing paper covers all four panels.

Fold all of the flaps and side lines, making sure that there's a stiff crease on all the edges. This will ensure that the lantern will stand up straight when finished. To finish, add a flameless candle or fairy lights.

HANGING FAN

These brightly colored, bohemian fans can take while to put together, but the results are stunning. By making several in a variety of colors and sizes you'll be able to create a striking display.

Here is the corrected text:

Assembled Models

You will need buttons, beads, Selection of papers, oil paints, glue and brush.

Greaseproof paper and stick.

Knife or Scorer.
PV/A glue and stick.

Here is the corrected text:

Decorations

To make a hanging fan, you will need:

* Sticky tape
* Assorted colors of paper (at least two)
* Cutting mat and ruler or straightedge
* PVA glue
* Glue stick
* Hot glue gun (optional)

Instructions:

1. Score equally spaced vertical lines on several sheets of paper. The more sheets you use and the wider the lines, the bigger the fan will be. Use the guides on your cutting mat to make sure the lines are straight.
2. Apply PVA glue to the bottom segment of one sheet of paper. Stick the top segment of another sheet of paper on top so they overlap. Allow to dry and then repeat with the other sheets (minimum of two).
3. Fold the papers along the scored creases to create an accordion effect.
4. Repeat this process with slimmer sheets of paper of a different color. When done, lay them flat and cut shapes into the folds to add detail.
5. Repeat again with another thinner paper. However, instead of cutting a design in the folds, slice the ends off diagonally.
6. Glue the third paper along the bottom edge of the fan. Make sure to take your time to ensure the edges align properly.

7. Apply PVA glue to one end, then bring the two sides of the accordion together to form a large circle.

8. Lay the fan on greaseproof paper and use a hot glue gun to create a pool of glue in the center, if desired.

Note: The original text contained many errors and inconsistencies, but I have done my best to correct it and make it readable.

Using both hands, carefully squeeze the tan inward so that the centre moves toward the glue and shrinks. Hold in place until the glue sets, then peel away the greaseproof paper. Neatly cut out the discs.

HANGING FAN

Turn the fan on its back and stick the plain disc to the centre with hot glue. Fold a ribbon in half, place the opposite ends on top, then secure in place with a strip of paper and some PVA glue. Then, stick the second disc on top with more hot glue.

Cover the hole on the front of your fan with buttons or beads.

DECORATIONS

Creating Flowers

Hold templates firmly.

Copy the templates to cardboard and cut them out. Draw two small petals to one side, then use a pencil to curl around them and cut out six small, ten medium, and six large petals from pink crepe paper. Then cut eight sepals and one large leaf from dark green crepe paper.

Push your thumbs into the center of the small petals to cup them. Push out the medium and large petals in the same way, but this time at three points on the petal.

Large Rose

Add a dab of hot glue to the bottom point of the two small uncurled petals and attach them to the dowelling. Apply glue to the top of the rod and roll the petals into a spiral around it.

Here is the corrected text:

Going from small to large. Attach the remaining petals in the same way, spacing by eye. Add glue further up the petal to keep the shape if need be. You also may have to stretch the base of the large petals to fit.

Place a line of hot glue along the centre of the large green leaf and attach the floral wire. Fold the leaf in half and allow the hot glue to set before opening again.

Starting at the base of the rose, wind the stem tape around the dowelling. After a few turns, add the wired leaf and glue it in place with the glue gun. Continue to wrap the stem tape around the dowelling until you reach the end.

Festival Headband

Festival headbands, while primarily worn at festivals, have become increasingly popular at weddings and springtime events. Most combinations of right flowers will work well.

Here is the corrected text:

You will need:

* 2d and 26-gauge wire
* Fldr-ist wire
* Ruler
* Pencils
* Paper
* Crepe paper
* Scissors
* Pliers
* Daisies
* Peonies
* Daffodils

Instructions:

Wrap two 36cm (14in) strips of 20-gauge wire in 1.5cm (5/8in) wide crepe paper, overlapping the ends of the wire by 7.5cm (3in).

Use crepe paper to secure the join.

FLOWERS

Measure your head with the wire, holding the point at which the two ends need to overlap. Glue in place.

Make five sterns with five leaves each. Spray mount two shades of green crepe paper together. Cut out 25 leaves and pinch to shape.

Wrap a 6cm (2 1/4 inch) length of 20-gauge wire with a 1-cm (1/2 inch) wide strip of crepe paper, tucking and gluing in the leaves between wraps.

FESTIVAL HEADBAND

Attach the leaf stems to the ring using 26-gauge wire. Keep the ends away from the inside of the ring. Trim the stems if necessary. Space the leaves out evenly, facing towards a focal point at the front of the ring. Leave a large gap at the back.

Here is the corrected text:

Attach the flowers using 26-gauge wire. Wrap the tip of wire in crepe paper, placing a large peony at the focal point and spacing other flowers around the headband. This will cover up any bits of wire and strengthen the ring.

Scrapbooking

121

Making a Scrapbook

Scrapbooks provide the perfect home for your photographs, letters, tickets, postcards, newspaper clippings, maps, gift tags, or anything else you find meaningful. The basic steps are simple: choose a theme and fill the book with mementos. After that, it's just a matter of adding embellishments and decorations to make them your own.

The beauty of scrapbooks is that they feel truly personal to you. While popular themes include weddings, family history, travel, or a baby's first year, you can make them for just about anything you treasure...

The following pages cover some of the basic tools and know-how you'll need to get started, but the secret to making the perfect scrapbook is simple - fill them with the things that mean the most to you.

Paper Punch



• Spiral-bound Scrapbook or Album

The following is a brief history of the development of computer hardware. 

Computer hardware refers to the physical components that make up a computer system. This includes the central processing unit (CPU), memory, input/output devices, and storage devices.

The first electronic computers were developed in the 1940s, using vacuum tubes as their main component. These early computers were massive and unreliable, but they paved the way for future developments.

In the 1950s, transistors replaced vacuum tubes, leading to smaller, faster, and more reliable machines. The mini-computer era began in the 1960s, with the introduction of small-scale integrated circuits (ICs).

The microcomputer revolution started in the 1970s, when personal computers were introduced. These early PCs used ICs and keyboard interfaces to process information.

The 1980s saw the rise of personal computers with graphical user interfaces (GUIs), such as Apple's Macintosh and Microsoft's Windows.

In the 1990s and 2000s, computer hardware continued to evolve with advancements in processor speed, memory capacity, and storage capabilities. Modern computers now use a range of technologies, including CPUs, GPUs, and solid-state drives (SSDs).

Paper, Simple but eye-catching, rosettes are a great way to adorn your pages and add a little extra charm. The accordion fold used to make them can be used to make embellishments such as a pram or crib, but what you do with them is up to you.

Basic Rosette

1. Draw and score a grid on a 20x8cm (8x3in) piece of paper.
Each section of the paper in the grid should be approximately half the length.
Be 1x4cm (12x11in). Attach the ends of the two lengths of folded
paper together with double-sided tape to form a circle.

Pram

1. Cut out a 3/4 inch deep rectangle from card and attach an accordion fold to the upper quarter using dot adhesive, double-sided tape.
Create wheels by sticking buttons to cardboard. Fill a piece of paper with an edge punch and glue.
Tie a short piece of ribbon into a bow.
